content.description:
Go up the obvious big corner to the top. 

  . . (I have not yet climbed this, though it looks good from the bottom. So the difficulty and quality ratings are my best guess based on reports from other people.   - > If you know better, please add a Comment below). 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
Trad: Standard rack. Â Nice spot for a #6 right off the ground - or just put a hand-sized piece in the crack to the right.

 For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Party Wall sector.
content.location:
The obvious wide crack in the big corner at the right end of the South (right) face of Party Wall. 

  --> See on this routes Photo

content.description:
Every move is thoughtful, but perhaps not every move is fun.  

  First aim for a two-feet-wide rectangular roof which is right-ward from below the obvious tree halfway up. Next aim diagonal left for that tree. Then up trending a bit left, to reach an obvious right-trending crack, and finish on that. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
Trad: Standard rack.

 For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Party Wall sector.
content.location:
About eight feet left from the right edge of the West (left) face of Party Wall. 

  --> See on this routes Photo

content.description:
Interesting arete moves, but then the arete ends. 

  Mount the arete from its right side, then up directly on the arete, and continue to the top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Party Wall sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
The arete or little ridge which forms the left edge of the South (right) face of Party Wall. 

  --> See on this routes Photo

content.description:
Some interesting moves, but the crux sequence is much harder than the rest. 

  Pass on the right of the steep tree, then a move up right, finish straight to the top. 

  ? or perhaps the original First Ascent started up the left-facing corner a bit further right -- and finished diagonalling right-ward). 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection: Trad: Standard rack.For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Party Wall sector.
content.location:
3-5 right of the narrow very steep gully between left edge of West (left) face of Party Wall and the right edge of the next wall, above a steep dirt slope. 

  ? Or perhaps the original First Ascent started up the right-facing corner around 8-10 feet right of the left edge of the West face ? 

  --> See on this routes Photo

content.description:
Thoughtful moves in a variety of rock situations. 

  Start in the overhanging alcove, up the crack, the roughly straight to the top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection: Trad: Standard rack.For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Party Wall sector.
content.location:
Dark alcove four feet wide at the bottom of a wide vertical crack. About ten feet right from the left edge of the South (left) face of Party Wall. 

  --> See on this routes Photo

content.description:
Fun moves with big handholds, sometimes a bit of thought required. 

  Up the right side of the narrow gully (passing on left side of tree) and up corners to the top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Interesting moves. 

  First pass right of small tree, next up along the right edge of the West (left) face of Party Wall -- to under a nose / circular roof with radius about three feet. Step Left around the roof and up to the top. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description: Interesting and hard moves through the crux in the middle section, followed by a juggy, pumpy and fun finish through a series of ledges and mini roofs.Â
content.protection: Top rope anchor can be set up with long static rope off of the thicker trees on the upper level. careful not to get the rope jammed in the small crack.
content.location: Up the face on the small wall to the right of short and sweet when facing party wall. Start on the lower right hand corner of the wall with the sharp flake that is about six feet off the ground and to the right of the rust colored strip of rock (put most of our weight on your feet as the chip feels like it could rip off any moment).Â Climb up and to the left towards the crack with the almond shaped indentation in it. Throw up to the series of ledges above or use footwork to get to the fun series of ledges that move up and left into and over the series of mini roofs.

content.description:
Top-Roping and bouldering in the midst of the Yankee Ramparts West area. 

  Mostly easier routes, 25-40 feet high. 

  Quiet atmosphere because there's a big hump between the cliff and the Thruway. 

  Top-Roping: With a static line off an obvious tree, could access six different routes from the same anchor.    Access the top of the cliff: One way is to walk flat NorthWest about 90 feet, then turn right and start hiking up in toward the next cliff sector, and find a narrow gully diagonal going up right-ward. 

  Photos of route lines:  

West face

South face
